SIR JOHN GIBBONS, BART. I live at Stanwell, in Middlesex. I have an enclosed piece of ground, called Stanwell-park
. On the night of the 5th of January, between twelve and one o'clock, my daughter gave an alarm that poachers were in my ground; I got up, and went down stairs - my son and a footman had gone out before me with Turner and Woolford; another man afterwards joined them; there were six of us in all - I met the poachers on the bank of an aqueduct in Stanwell-park; there were seven or eight of them who had guns and bludgeons; every man was armed, as far as I could see - I met them, and my men were following them; I went into the midst of them, and seized one with a gun in his hand - he struck me with his gun, and others came to his assistance; I received bruises on my arm and on my head, which have but just gone off - the man and myself fell down together; my hat had been previously knocked off - while I was on the ground I heard the words,"D-n it, it must be done;" it was not said in a very savage way, and at that moment a blow was struck at me with a bludgeon, which I think must have killed me, had it not just missed me; it grazed my head - after some struggling I and the man I had hold of (one of the poachers) were up together, and at that moment one of my men seized him, and he was down again; I think it was the same man - there was a considerable scuffle with my own men and the poachers; I thought the one, who was down, was secure, and said "Keep him in custody, make sure of him;" the other poachers ran away, but quickly returned and rescued that man - they were pursued, but got away; there were arms levelled in all ways, but I did not see any thing done with them; I heard no more till some of them were in custody - Pond was, I believe, the first who was taken, and confessed as he has now; Carrod said he had been of the party, and that it was the first time - White pleaded for mercy, and said he had a wife and children, but he did not deny the fact; there are game in that park.

DANIEL COTTELL
. I am a labourer, and live at Stanwell. I was in Stanwell-park on the night of the 5th of January; when I first saw the men they were hailed by the footman and gardener; as they were coming out of the wood they said, "Stand off, for our guns are loaded"- five of them had guns; I saw Sir John Gibbons down with one of the party, and a gun was levelled at him, a trigger was pulled, and fire struck; there was a flash not more than three yards from him, and it was levelled at him; I saw all the prisoners at the bar there - there were eight or nine persons there.
COURT. Q.Have you any doubt that they were there for the purpose of destroying game? A. No.

CHARLES COODREE. I am a patrol. I assisted in taking Pond into custody, and the next morning we took the other two; White asked whether we had gone after any of the people down at Datchet; we said No - he then asked whether we had Carrod; we said No - he said he would go and show us his house; I had not told him what I took him for - while he stood in the street with my partner he said five of the others were to be found at Datchet; Carrod said but very little - he put on his shoes and stockings, and said he hoped he should not go to Clerkenwell; they asked if we had seen any of those who were with them, and who lived at Datchet; we said No.
Carrod. No. one of the witnesses can say they saw me with a gun or a stick.

DANIEL COTTELL
. I saw him; he had a bludgeon.

WHITE -
GUILTY .

CARROD -
GUILTY .

All three
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoners.

460.
MARY HALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 3d., the goods of
Cornelius Daley
; 1 apron, value 6d., the goods of
Cornelius Keefe
; 2 sheets, value 6s.; 1 gown, value 4s., and 1 flat iron, value 6d. , the goods of
Timothy Doyle
.

ELLEN DALEY
. I am the wife of
Cornelius Daley
, and live in Charles-street, Drury-lane
; I let a lodging to the prisoner one Thursday; she staid but three nights, and left at half-past six o'clock in the morning; I missed these things, and at Bow-street they were taken from her person - I saw her with this handkerchief round her neck.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ANN DOVLE
. I am the wife of Timothy Doyle; these sheets and gown are mine.

GEORGE KETTERER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, a gown, and iron, pawned on the 14th of December.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the duplicates of these things; I did not sleep in that woman's house.

GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

461.
THOMAS BRODERICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
Edward Blake
.

EDWARD BLAKE
. I keep a shaving-shop in William-street, Lisson-grove
. On the 6th of December I missed a pocket-handkerchief from my room, and on the 10th I missed another; the prisoner came on the 6th to see his father, who lodged with me; I found the handkerchief which I missed on the 10th, down the prisoner's bosom.
Prisoner. My father is a reputed thief, and he told me to steal the handkerchief and put it into my bosom.

EDWARD BLAKE
. His father is a servant out of place - he has been with me four or five months, and has pains in his limbs, and could not get a situation; the prisoner slept with a man who paid me 2s. 6d. a week for his bed.

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Whipped and Discharged.

462.
JOHN BENSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of January , 3 loaves of bread, value 1s. , the goods of
William Goodwin
.

The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

463.
JOHN BEAZLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January , 1 silver spoon, value 5s. , the goods of
William Phillips
.

GEORGE PROCTOR. I am a waiter to William Phillips, of the White Horse inn, Friday-street
- the prisoner used to bring fish there. On the 19th of January I saw him with some fish, and paid him for some between twelve and one o'clock - I missed a spoon between eight and nine.

JACOB RUSSELL. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Shoreditch. The prisoner brought this spoon to pawn - he gave an address I thought was not right; I asked if he had any objection to my going there - he said No; I went to the officer, and gave information.

JAMES HANDLEY
. I am an officer; the prisoner and this spoon were given to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It was given to me; I am no scholar, and could not read what was on it - they let me go, and I resigned myself up by their direction next morning.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Confined Six Weeks .

464.
JOHN EARLIDGE
and
ELIZABETH EARLIDGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 2 blankets, value 22s., and 1 rug, value 4s. , the goods of
William Stevens
.

WILLIAM GIRLING
. I live in Mitchell-street, just behind St. Luke's church, about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's. On the 7th of December, about half-past seven o'clock, I was crossing Goswell-street, and saw the female prisoner with a large bundle; I went into the Hat and Feathers about twenty yards distance, and saw the male prisoner come in company with her into the house - they had something to drink and went out - they separated; I watched the woman to Hatton-garden, and gave charge of her.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Are you one of the Police? A. No, but I thought proper to watch her.

THOMAS MORFORD
. I am a Police-constable. I took the female prisoner, and have had the bundle ever since; I asked what she had got - she said blankets, and she was going to take them to the Borough; I said I thought it was unreasonable to take a bundle at that time - she said she lived at Euston-terrace; I did not like her manner, and took her to the watch-house - I went to the place she mentioned and no such person was known there; she afterwards said where she got them from.
Cross-examined. Q.Was the male prisoner discharged? A. Yes, on the 12th; I took him again yesterday week - he went to a public-house with his brother, who gave his word that he would not let him go.

WILLIAM STEVENS
. I live at No. 15, Goswell-street. The male prisoner lived with me as shopman , and slept in my house - he was there on the 7th of December; I am not aware whether his wife came to see him - this rug and blanket belong to me; I deal in horse cloths and blankets - these were taken from the back part of my shop; I did not miss them till the officer brought them.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there a person here named Duffield? A. No; I succeeded him in the business; he was in the habit of dealing with me - the prisoner might enter any thing he purchased - there has been an entry in my book in the name of Duffield, but it has been scratched out by Mr. Duffield, because he did not order the goods; he lives about four hundred yards from me - the male prisoner left my shop about two o'clock in the afternoon on the 7th of December, and I did not see him again till he was in custody; he was not discharged by me, but he was let out of custody on the 12th of December, and was taken again last Monday at his brother's in the City, because I had fresh evidence from a person named Crute, a green-grocer - I knew Crute, but he told me nothing of this till Monday week: my book is not here.

COURT. Q.Are you able to say whether the male prisoner was at your house on the morning of the 7th of December? A. Yes, about seven o'clock in the morning - I saw Duffield scratch out the entry, which had been made by
John Earlidge
.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM CRUTE. At half-past seven o'clock on the morning of the 7th of December I was going to Newgate-market, and saw the female prisoner come out of the prosecutor's house with a bundle in a rug - I saw it was a blanket.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the shop? A. I saw the woman come out, and saw the man shut the door; it struck me it was all right.

J. EARLIDGE -
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .

E. EARLIDGE -
NOT GUILTY .

465.
GEORGE WESTLAKE
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE DURANT
. I am a surgeon and a lecturer on anatomy . I authorised the prisoner to receive 50l. from a gentleman named Wise - he told me he had received 40l., which he has never paid me; he was to receive it as my agent.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Was he not your attorney? A. Of course he was - I was informed he was an attorney; I had not employed him for any business before - I have since.
NOT GUILTY .

466.
JOHN MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of January , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Daniel Mesman
, from his person .

DANIEL MESMAN
. On the 12th of January, about half-past three o'clock, I was crossing towards the Haymarket; a man tapped me on the shoulder, said "You have lost your handkerchief, and here is the lad I saw pick your pocket;" I turned, and he had my handkerchief; I took it, and collared the prisoner - I gave him to the officer with it.

GEORGE WATSON
. I saw the prosecutor passing Piccadilly
; the prisoner and another walked close behind him - I watched, and saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the pocket; I told the gentleman.

WILLIAM LONDON
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

467.
JAMES HOOK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of December
, 400lbs. weight of twine, value 11l. 19s., and 12 skeins of cord, value 1s. , the goods of
Edward Newman
;
JOHN WAKELEY
and
SAMUEL GODDARD
were indicted for
feloniously receiving 36lbs. weight of twine, value 29s., and 12 skeins of cord, value 1s., part of the said goods, well knowing it to have been stolen .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

EDWARD NEWMAN
. I am a rope-maker , and live at Deptford. On the morning of the 16th of December I went to my warehouse fronting Deptford-creek
; and found the premises were broken open in two parts - I missed rope and twine to the value of nearly 60l.; I remember, on the 11th of December, three men came to my warehouse, and I have not the least doubt that Hook was one of them - they came to sell some old rope, and two of them went to the window, where it is unusual for such men to go; it struck me that they took more than usual notice of the premises - they were looking about a particular window, which was one that was broken open.
COURT. Q.Was the cord and twine in a state in which it could be sold? A.Part of it was.

JAMES VALLOR
. I am foreman to Mr. Newman. On the 16th of December I went to his premises, and saw the window broken; a ticket in my own hand-writing, which had been in the warehouse on the night of the 15th, was afterwards shown to me at the Thames Police-office - that ticket had been with the twine, and was missed from the warehouse; if it had been sold, the ticket would have been taken off - when I take twine out for sale, I take off the ticket before I enter it in the book; I afterwards saw some twine and a bundle of cord at the Thames Police-office.

ELIZABETH FITCH
. I am the wife of James Fitch. The prisoner Hook came to our house on the 17th of December; my husband was not at home - Hook asked me for the horse and cart, which I lent him; the cart was empty when he took it away, between five and six o'clock in the evening - he brought it back in about an hour, nearly full of rope and twine; it remained there till the evening of the 21st, and was then taken away.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Had you seen Hook before that? A. Yes; I do not know the prosecutor's premises.

JAMES FITCH
. I live at No. 1, Sydney-street, Poplar. On the 18th of December I saw Hook, whom I have known some years: he engaged me to drive this rope and twine over to the Borough, and promised to meet me there, but he did not come - I brought it back to my own yard, and it remained there till the 21st, when it was taken away; on Sunday, the 20th, I saw Hook, Wakeley, and another man - they were looking about my yard, and at the cart, and the goods in it; I was in the stable - they afterwards came into the stable to me, and asked if I or Amsdell were going to stand any thing to drink; I fetched some gin, and it was drank between us.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Then you had these in your possession four or five days? A. It was there from the 17th to the 21st; any one might have seen it - Wakeley had hired my cart before; he is a marine-store dealer, I believe; Amsdell is a baker, and his cart stands on my premises - I did not stand the drink.
COURT. Q. How long have you known Hook? A. Four or five years; he is a fisherman - the twine was a great deal like fishermens' twine - I had no suspicion but that it was his property.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Was it small twine? A. Yes.

AMELIA FITCH
. I am daughter of James Fitch: I know Hook; I saw him in the yard, and Wakeley came while he was there - they were looking into the cart.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q.Did you not show Wakeley the way into the yard? A. Yes; I saw him conversing with Hook, and go away.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Were you at home on the Friday or Saturday? A. No, I was at my aunt's; I have known Hooks a long while.

JOHN AMSDELL
. I am a baker, and live at No. 44, Well-street, Poplar; I keep a horse and cart at Mr. Fitch's yard. On the 20th of December I went to have my horse cleaned; I saw Hook and Fitch there, and I afterwards saw Wakeley - Fitch was in the stable, doing up his horse - I was doing the same; I saw Hook and Wakeley looking into the cart, which was there, and had some rope and line in it - there was some gin fetched.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is Fitch a friend of yours? A. No, not particularly so, only I have kept my horse and cart there about sixteen months, and pay him.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Who paid for the gin? A.Wakeley - I did not notice that Fitch looked into the cart; he did not exercise any authority over it.

HENRY TURNER
. On the 20th of December I went by the side of the water at Limehouse-cut; I saw Goddard and two other men raking little bundles of rope out of the cut with a rake and a boat-hook; I knew Goddard before- he said to me, "Don't take notice;" I am sure he said that - he was laying the bundles of rope on the side of the bank; I had seen him a day or two before, near the same place, with a sack, which appeared full of something - I asked him how heavy it was; he said very heavy, and I said he might put it into my cart - he did so, and a good way further on he took it out and put it on his shoulder; he asked me to drive on, because he wanted to make haste - the roads were very slippery, and it would not have been safe for me to have gone fast; it appeared to me there was some rope-yarn in it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.What day was it? A. I cannot tell: I believe it was on a Tuesday - it was in December; I had a butt and some wash in it; I was in Bromley-lane; it was about two days before I saw Goddard with the other men; I do not know whether they were White and Judge, the officers - I did not say at the office that they were; I said I could not tell whether they were there or not - I did at first say White was one and Judge the other, and swore so; I believe the day was before Christmas - I will not swear that; it was between seven and eight o'clock in the morning -
Isaac King
was with me; I did not observe any person going by.

THOMAS GRAY
. I am a Thames Police-officer. On the 23rd of December I apprehended Hook at his house; I told him it was on suspicion of a robbery at Mr. Newman's, at Deptford-creek - I did not threaten or promise him any thing, but the next day he told me that two men in a ship's boat, came and brought a quantity of line and twine to him - that he had hired a cart of Fitch's, and Fitch was not at home; he said he did not know the man who brought it to him, but he was to dispose of it, if hecould; that he could not dispose of it, and took it to Limehouse-cut, and hove it overboard; I asked if he knew the two men; he said he would tell me no more, as he had told me enough; I went to Wakeley's on the 22nd (I believe) with Judge and White - I found a quantity of lines, twines, and a bundle of box cord; some of them were in a water-butt; the officer who executed the warrant asked him about them, and he said Goddard brought them to his house - Wakeley is a dealer in marine-stores, and keeps a melting place: he had a crucible on the fire, and ran down 2 cwt. of metal while we were there: he is in an extensive line.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you been an officer? A.Thirteen years; I never saw any silver melted at Wakeley's, but I have copper - it might be in his way of trade; he was in his back premises - the place is open in the day time; there was some new copper concealed under some sacks - White took that, but we have found no charge against him for that, but he could not give a satisfactory account of it before the Magistrate; he has been employed at that for years; I saw the twine found in the butt - I was at the cut on the 24th or 25th, I believe - I did not see Turner there; it was in the afternoon - I found some rope, which was rather dirty; that was not the reason which Wakeley assigned for putting it into the water-butt.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.You did not persuade Hook to say any thing? A. No; I did not upon my oath - he boys some sort of twine for use in his business; I asked if he knew the two men, and he said he did not - I did not caution him against telling any thing.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q.What time did you go to the cut? A.About twelve o'clock.

WILLIAM JUDGE. I went with this witness and White to Wakeley's premises, and in a stable, at the back of the premises; I saw a water-butt - I found something in it, got the tongs, and found a bundle of twelve skeins of box cord - Goddard and Wakeley were both present; I went the next day to the cut, with White, Gray, and Hughes, and found twenty-two skeins of what is called ground twine and thirty-eight skeins of twine and line - this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q.What did either Wakeley or Goddard say? A.Goddard said, "We washed it all there;" we went to the cut, because Goddard said, if any body would go with him to the place, he would show where he took it up; he said, there was some more, no doubt - on the first day I had only a boat-hook and a rake to get it out, and on the second day, I got a pair of drags.

JAMES WHITE
. I am a Thames Police-officer; I went to Wakeley's. and found him in the melting place, and Goddard with him; I said I came to look for some rope and twine, Wakeley said, "Very well, look round" - I looked round and found it - Wakeley said Goddard brought it in about an hour before: Goddard said he had been to drown a cat in the cut, and had found it swimming there; I am sure he said that - Judge found twelve skeins of cord, but I was not there.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Then what Wakeley said, turned out to be true? A. Yes.
MR. NEWMAN. None of these articles would swim, they would sink like stones.

ALEXANDER HUGHES
. I am an officer of the Thames Police; I found this ticket on part of the twine pulled out of the cut.

JAMES VALLOR
. This is the ticket which was on the ground twine at Mr. Newman's; I have looked at all the property, and believe it is all, that which was stolen from his premises.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Can you swear to this ticket as your hand-writing? A. Yes; it is never sent out with the goods - it is my place to take it off, and enter the goods in the book; I have sent out the goods ever since I have been there.

MR. HEATON to MR. NEWMAN. Q. Is the cord in the state, in which it is sold? A. It is a little altered with the wet - it has all little pieces of string to which tickets have been attached, and they have been torn off, which they are not when it is sold; the persons who came to me on the 11th of December, came to sell rope - we frequently buy old rope.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have customers any thing to do with the window, you saw Hook examining? A. No.
Wakeley's Defence. I am, it is true, numbered with marine store dealers, but my trade is a brass and copper manufacturer.
Goddard's Defence. I found the articles.

HOOK -
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

WAKELEY -
GUILTY . Aged 40.

GODDARD -
GUILTY . Aged 40.

468.
RICHARD JAMES PRICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 6 shirts, value 13s., the goods of
Thomas Riley
; and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
Ann Brown
.

THOMAS RILEY
. I am a shoemaker . On the 9th of December. I was at a back room, which I rent at the Crown in Ratcliff-highway
; I was asleep by the fire, and had six shirts in a bundle on the table - I did not see the prisoner at all; he left the door open when he went out.

ELEANOR DEAL
. I was at the public-house; I saw the prisoner come out of his room, with a bundle under his right arm.

THOMAS HOOD
. I am a waiter at the public-house; I saw the prisoner come up the passage, and go out at the street door with a blue bundle under his arm - he came back without the bundle; the things have never been found since.

RICHARD MALLETT
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 9th of December the prisoner came and offered six shirts to pawn; one white one, one flannel one, and four dark cotton ones - I did not like his appearance, and offered him half the money he asked, and he went away.

GEORGE DEVERELL. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; when he was brought by the headborough he said he had been searched - he said the bundle he took out belonged to a girl in the public-house, named Sarah, but he could not tell where she lived, nor her other name; I asked what it contained - he said the image of a broken cow; I went and found the girl and brought her - she said to him,"You need not wink at me. I will not tell a lie for you, my bundle contained a broken cow and nothing else."

Prisoner's Defence. I and my brother William wentthere to breakfast; a young woman came in and said,"William, if any one comes and asks for me, tell them I am gone up Ratcliff-highway:" when the girl came back she had a bundle with a lot of images in it, and she pulled out five images and a broken cow, to ornament the taproom.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

469.
ISAAC PICKERING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of December , 1 iron mortar, value 5s. the goods of
James Field
.

JAMES FIELD
. I lodge at the prisoner's mother's in Southampton-court
; this iron mortar was just out at the back-door - it was not for sale

MARIA BROWN
. I keep a marine-store shop, in Portpool-lane; I bought this of the prisoner on the 10th of December, for 1s. 6d. - he gave the name of Jones.
PHILIP BROWN. The prisoner sold this to my mother, and gave the name of Jones.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

470.
JOSEPH READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 1 pair of boots, value 4s. , the goods of
George Henry Dowdeswell
.

MARY DOWDESWELL
. I am the wife of
George Henry Dowdeswell
; he keeps a clothes-warehouse in Hoxton Old Town
. On the 2nd of December the prisoner came and took these boots off the counter; as I was sitting in my parlour I heard a noise in the shop - I got up and gave the alarm, and he was taken immediately; he came in on his hands and knees, I suppose, but he walked out.

JOHN PEARSON
. I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoner come out of the shop - I took him and the witness took the boots.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

471.
MARY OUSLEY
.
JANE COLLINS
,
RICHARD CORNBY
, and
JOHN DAVID OUSLEY
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of December , 1 watch, value 2l., the goods of
Thomas Lee
, from his person ; and that at the Delivery of his Majesty's Gaol of Newgate, on Thursday, the 11th of May, in the 7th year of his present Majesty's reign, the said
Mary Ousley
was convicted of felony, by the name of
Mary Ouswell
.

THOMAS LEE
. I am a labourer . On the 26th of December I was at the Royal Hospital, near Chelsea College
, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening; I was sober; the four prisoners were all there in company, and the two girls sat one on each side of me; the men were in the box - I had a watch in my fob, which I missed while I was there; I got up and went to the bar to explain it to the publican, and one of my witnesses said they knew the party who had drawn it - I never got it again.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you quite sober? A. Yes; I went on Monday morning to the watch-house keeper.
THOMAS DAVIES. I was at the public-house, and saw Lee there, and the prisoners - I saw Collins hand a watch to Cornby, who walked off with it; I suppose he went out - I did not see the others go.

Cross-examined. Q.What are you? A. A shoemaker; this was up in a corner in the tap-room - I do not think it was the girl's own watch; I did not give an alarm that moment, but when I was asked, I did - I thought it looked rather suspicious, for the girl to give the man the watch, and he to go out with it: I did not know who it belonged to - Cornby came back to the place, but did not stop; he was not taken that night - he could not be found.

WILLIAM WINTER
. I just stepped into the house, being rather cold; I saw these two girls right and left of the prosecutor - they were trying his pockets; the young woman took the watch from his pocket and the signal was given to Cornby - I went to the bar and told a young woman; Cornby went out and returned to the tap-room in about ten minutes.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did you ever say that John David Ousley went out with the watch? A. No; he crossed to the end of the table, but the others went out with the watch.

Cross-examined. Q.Then he had no part in stealing it? A. No - I saw it delivered from one to the other - Cornby was on the side of me with a basket, but had no fruit in it; he was not near, nor aiding, or assisting in stealing it.

WILLIAM BARTON
. I took the two female prisoners on the night of the robbery, and Ousley on the 7th of January, from information which I received; he said he knew who had the watch, but he would see us d-d before he would tell us.
John David Ousley. I did not say any thing of the kind.
Cornby's Defence. I had apples - I went in, and Collins sold them to the landlord's sister for 6d.

Collins' Defence. I went and sold the apples, and when I came back this young woman asked me to have a drop of something to drink; I took it, went to the fireplace, and was there when the man said he had lost his watch.

WILLIAM COLLINS. I am a constable of Chelsea. I have a certificate of the conviction of
Mary Ouswell
; she had three months in the House of Correction - I was at the trial before your Lordship; the prisoner Ousley is the person.

MARY OUSLEY
-
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .

COLLINS -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

CORNBY -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

JOHN DAVID
OUSLEY -
NOT GUILTY .

472.
EDWARD WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of December , 1 watch, value 3l., and 2 watchkeys, value 6d., the goods of
Dennis Sweeney
, from his person .

DENNIS SWEENEY
. I went to a funeral on the 13th of December, and the prisoner was one of the party; we went into a public-house, and had about three gallons of beer; we then went to another house, and had some more- when I came out I pulled out my watch, and looked at it; I asked my brother-in-law the time, and the prisoner came and put his hand round me - I thought it was out of friendship; my watch was taken from me, and the prisoner put his hand behind him to his brother, as he called him - I kept the prisoner till he was taken,
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Was he not liberated that night? A. Yes; I perhaps had not drank half a gallon - I had had as much as would do me good.

ELIZABETH SWEENEY
. I was behind my husband when the prisoner drew him of his watch; my husband took him by the collar.
Cross-examined. Q.What were you drinking? A.Beer, and the women had a little gin and water; the prisoner was set at liberty, but he gave the watch to his brother.
NOT GUILTY .

473.
ANN WALTERS
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of December , 1 tea-tray, value 10s. , the goods of
James Morrison
.

MARY MORRISON. I am the wife of James Morrison. A young man came to bring medicine to our lodger; I left him at the door while they came down - I thought I heard some person go along the passage; I went up, found the parlour door open, and the tea-tray gone - I believe the young man took it, and gave it to the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

474.
ANN WALTERS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January , 1 pelisse, value 10s.; 2 gowns, value 12s., and 2 caps, value 4s., the goods of
Eliza Launchbury
; and 1 watch, value 10s.; 1 coat, value 7s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 8s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 apron, value 3d. , the goods of
John Wigmore
.

ELIZA LAUNCHBURY. I lost my property from where I lodge, in Green-street
, on the 11th of January, about five o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoner in the room - she was a stranger; the things were packed up in two separate bundles - I had the prisoner taken.

JOHN WIGMORE
. I lodge on the second-floor back room. This watch, coat, breeches, shirt, handkerchief, and apron, are mine, and were in my room; I had left the key in the door for the young man who lodges with me.

JAMES MORGAN
. I took this watch from the prisoner, and went to her lodgings - of all the distress I ever saw I think that was the greatest; the children had not a bit of food or fire.

Prisoner's Defence, written. I was unfortunately led away by a person, named Eliza Case, who informed me she was proprietor of the said property, and told me where the key of the room was deposited, and gave me every information where the property now produced was to be found. which I found as the said
Eliza Case
told me; when I entered the room I found the articles as she stated to me - before I left the room the real proprietor of the lodgings came into the room, charge was given of me, and I was taken to Hatton Garden Office, and remanded for a second examination, but not finding Case I was committed.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Transported for Seven Years .

475.
GEORGE WASE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of January , 1 book, value 2s. , the goods of
George Thomas Clemmans
.

GEORGE THOMAS CLEMMANS
. I keep a broker's shop in Hackney-road
- I lost this book on the 13th of January.

HENRY CHOULES
. I saw the prisoner go to the shop about three o'clock, reach over, and take a book - he opened it, and I think some body came up to the shop; he walked away, and put the book into his pocket - we ran after him, but could not find him then; he was taken about seven o'clock - I had known him well; he worked for my father, and is a cabinet-maker - the book has not been found.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

476.
HENRY SAUNDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of December , 1 half-crown, 15 shillings, and 4 sixpences , the monies of
Charles Garrett
.

CHARLES GARRETT
. I live in Hampshire - I had been here from a fortnight before Christmas. On the 31st of December I fell in with the prisoner and another man, about four o'clock in the afternoon, in Whitechapel; his companion spoke to me first, and we went into a public-house; the prisoner came in soon afterwards - we had a pint of ale; the prisoner spoke to the other man, and said he had lent a woman 5l. in the morning to go and get a bonnet - I told him he would never see the bonnet nor the money any more; he said he had been to the Bank, and had 800l. - I did not believe that; he asked if I had any money, and wanted me to pull it out -I pulled 19s. 6d. out of a purse, laid it on the table, and one of them put it into a hat; the other man then called me to the door, and said he was going to get change for a draft - he told me to go back, and take care of the prisoner; I went back to the room, but the prisoner was gone, and the money; I had been out of the room but a very few minutes - I had only 1 1/2d. left; I saw the prisoner in a week afterwards - there was no other person in the room who could have taken it; there was another door on the left-hand side.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you told us all that happened? A. Yes; I did not tell the Magistrate that Dawson, the officer, told me what to say - I dare say I should not have come here if it had not been for him; I did not toss for any gin, but we drank 6d. of gin and water, which the prisoner paid for - the prisoner and the other man tossed, but I did not; there was some chalk made on the table, which they called their game, but I did not join in it - there was a piece of paper put into my hand, which they called a note, but I think it was not a note; I did not play any game with them - there was no other person in the tap-room; a boy brought in the gin and water; both the prisoner and his companion ran away - I did not call the landlord; the officer came in, and asked what I had been about - I told him; he had been watching them he told me; he went with my brother to look for them the next day - I do not remember the officer telling me what to say.

CHARLES DAWSON
. I am a Bow-street patrol, and have been so for four years. I was in Whitechapel a little after four o'clock, on the 31st of December; I saw the prisoner and a man named Duffey - seeing them with the prosecutor I watched them; they went down Brick-lane, and went into the Frying Pan - I said about twenty minutes, and saw the prosecutor and Duffey come to one door; the prisoner came out at another, and ran down Thrawl-street - Duffey left the prosecutor, and went towards Spitalfields; I went and asked the prosecutor if he had lost any thing, and from what he said I took the prisoner on the following Thursday.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you the Mr. Dawson who was at the Session once? A. Yes - I stood in the dock there, and had to pay 5l., but it was for no bad action - it was for assaulting a watchman; I was not in prison - I went there when I heard I was wanted; I did see Lewis before the Magistrate - I did not tell the prosecutor what to say; it was my duty to ask him how he had lost his money: he said before the Magistrate that I had not told him what to say.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent.

LEWIS LEWIS
. I am steward of a ship. I was in the watch-house when the officer brought in the prisoner - the next morning the prisoner wanted some person to go and fetch his brother, but Dawson gave strict charge that no person was to see him: I interceded with a beadle, and he gave me permission to go for his brother, who came down with me; I was in the office next morning, and Dawson told the prosecutor to say he laid down the money through fear, and he tutored him what to say - I am sure he said so; I told the prisoner's brother; little did I think I should he called on here.
COURT. Q. How came you to be at the watch-house? A. There was a fire, and I helped to extinguish it - I was to be paid for going to the prisoner's brother.

JOHN VAUX
. I was at the Magistrate's when the prisoner was examined; he wished the Magistrate to ask the prosecutor whether he was not tutored to say that he had put the money down through fear - he said he was, and he was not to say he had been tossing; this officer is the man that said it - I have employed the prisoner four years to drive the Brighton and Bristol vans.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

477.
HENRY TOMKINS
,
JOHN BENNETT
, and
THOMAS CHITTENDEN
were indicted for
breaking and entering the counting-house of the
Imperial gas-light and Coke Company
, on the 17th of December , and stealing 20 sovereigns, 12 half sovereigns, 20 crowns, 40 half crowns, 60 shillings, 20 sixpences, 1l. 5s. in copper monies, two 30l., one 40l. and one 5l. Bank notes, 1 order for payment of 50l, 1 order for 5l. 7s. 6d., and 1 order for 4l. 14s. , their property.
MESSRS. BRODRICK & PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN GALLATY VICKERS. I am superintendent of the works of the Imperial Gas Company, in Shoreditch
parish. On the 16th of December, at six o'clock in the evening, I made up my cash in the evening; I made up my cash as usual - the total amount was 210l. 16s., in cash and cheques; I put them into the iron safe, and locked it - I took the key out and locked the room, and took that key with me; on the next morning I was going there, and met the watchman - I found the door of the room latched, but not locked, and all the money was gone from the safe: there was no appearance of any force having been used- this counting-house is not attached to the dwelling-house - I recollect there was a 50l. cheque and two other cheques, 1l. 5s. tied up in copper, besides the cash and notes belonging to the Imperial Gas Company - the cheques were returned on the Tuesday.
COURT. Q. Had either of the prisoners been in the employ of the Company. A. Yes, two of them; Chittenden had been discharged about a month.

JOHN REYNOLDS. I am a smith, and live at No. 5, Hare-street, Hoxton. In December Bennett introduced me to Tomkins, as I had asked him for work, about eight o'clock in the morning; it was on a Saturday - Bennet told me Tomkins was the foreman of the works; I went and asked him if he could give me work - Tomkins told me he should like to see me at the Gun in Shoreditch; I went there between twelve and one o'clock, and Tomkins said he had got a job in hand, and where could he meet me on the Monday - I appointed the
Robin Hood
and Little John, and met him there between six and seven o'clock; he came in while I was there taking a pint of beer with a man named Balls - Tomkins asked me to walk out with him, and we went as far as the new church, Haggerstone; I asked him what the job was - he said, it was to break open the iron chest of the Imperial Gas-house, which must be done on a Wednesday night, as there was most money in it then; I said I did not understand it myself, and he might apply to other persons who would do it much better- he said he had applied to others, who had disappointed him; I said I did not wish to have any thing to do with it- I went home and spoke to Balls of what had passed; I went to Tomkins two days after the robbery, and said,"You have done the job you wanted me to do" - he said,"No, I have not done it, I can prove I was in bed and asleep at the time; I had a man at my place with the tools and keys to do it with, but I had put it so far in his hands, that he went out at the beginning of the evening and did it" - I then went home; Bennett came after that, and said Tomkins, the foreman, had sent me 30s., and we had a drop of hot together - two days after Christmas, I met Tomkins, who gave me 30s. more, and said, "I hope you won't say any thing about the robbery, as you were seen with Bennett, you are very likely to be taken up;" I told him where I lived, and said, "You may send Mr. Vickers, or any one to me, and I will clear myself, and pay the 30s. when I get work" - I went down to Balls, and told him what had passed; on the Saturday morning, Balls went and gave information; I was sent for - I went before the gentlemen of the Company, I think about a week after I saw Tomkins.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You have been a smith? A. Yes, and in the bedstead line, and can turn my hand to any thing in the labouring line; I was intimate with Balls - I have done hay-work for Mr. Rhodes; I was not taking up dead bodies on the 6th of March, no one can say that; I do not know whether I was charged with stealing dead bodies on the 6th of March - I might be taken up for getting the worse for a drop of liquor; you cannot bring any one to swear that I was taken up for breaking into a church-yard and stealing dead bodies- that might be a charge against me or it might not; I have taken goods to Camberwell, but never was in Camberwell new church-yard, and do not know where it is -I never was charged with stealing dead bodies from there; I do not know whether I was in custody at all on the 6th of March - if I was ever charged with stealing dead bodies it was unknown to me; I do not know a man of the name of William Burt, who lives in Mill-row, Kingsland - I never went by the name of Read; I know Phillips, who lives in Bridgewater-gardens, by sight and by drinking with him - I do not know that I was withPhillips in Camberwell new church-yard on the 6th of February, or in any church-yard; I was never charged with stealing dead bodies from St. Thomas', Hospital, which were afterwards returned from the London University - I do not know a man of the name of Sherrin, or Sherrill: I never borrowed a sack of him, and took it back the following morning - I do not know such a person as
William Burt
, and I did not meet him against the Hand and Sheers, in Cloth-fair.

Q. Did you not ask him how he got on for work? and did not you tell him you could put him into a plan, by which he could get some money - he asked you how, and you said, the foreman at the gas manufactory had a good situation, and he might go to him and say, if he did not send you money, you would go and tell his master he had done the robbery; and if Burt did not know him, you would go and show him the person? A. I do not know the man.

Q. Do you know this man a witness)? A. I have seen him about with a man of the name of
Tom Sheels
, who went breaking open Shoreditch dead-house, but I did not know his name; the reason I said I never saw this man was, because I did not know his name - I did see him in a public-house; I do not know whether it was near Cloth-fair - I do not know such a place; what you have stated as passing between him and me respecting the Gas Company is not true, so help me God - he did not say "I do not like the job;" nor I did not say I would go and try it on, but I hoped he would say nothing about it - Balls is here to-night, he came with me, and he was here last night - he is no relation of mine; he lives at No. 6, Canal-road; no person was present when the conversation took place between Tomkins and I - I did not then know Tomkins' name; I knew him by having seen him once before, but he asked me to break open the iron chest, there is no mistake about that - I stated before the Magistrate that he said there was a man in his house with the tools - that he had put it in his power, and he had done it unknown to him; I heard of a reward of 50l. after I got the last 30s. - I saw it on the wall near the factory; I did not hear it from Balls.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. You were never accused of stealing dead bodies? A. No; I was the worse for liquor. and was sent to Guildford as a vagrant - that was some time last year.

THOMAS BALLS
. I am a smith and farrier. I went to get a pint of beer at the Robin Hood and Little John, in Hoxton with Reynolds - I saw Tomkins there; he stopped a few minutes, and went out with Reynolds - I do not know what day it was - I never paid any regard to it; I went to Tomkins' house, in Margaret-street, near the Gas Company's works, on Saturday week - I tapped him on the shoulder, and said this business must be settled on better terms between Reynolds and him; he said, "Reynolds! I do not know such a man;" I said,"Do not you know the young man to whom you proposed to do that job for you at the counting-house?" he said,"I don't know him;" I said, "You must know the young man you gave 3l. to, to say nothing about it" - he went in, and staid about ten minutes, when he came out and said, "I can't see the other parties to-day;" I said, "It must be settled to-day between one and two o'clock, there is 50l. reward, and you must do the best you can, or things will go forward in the job" - he said,"Will you have any thing to drink?" I said, "I do not mind," and we went into a public-house, I believe the Antelope - I said I did not like gin, and we had a quartern of rum; we came out, and he said, "I will meet you to-morrow at the Robin Hood and Little John, between four and five o'clock" - I said that would do, but I did not go.

Cross-examined. Q.Did you tell the Magistrate that Tomkins said, "I can't see the parties to-day?" A. Yes: I did work for Mr. Rhodes - I left him when he left off business; I was not discharged for improper practices -I got 30s. a week then; I have since worked for two or three different shops - I cannot say exactly when I did the last job; I have not been intimate with Reynolds - I did not know he was at Guildford; I know
Bill Sherrill
and
Jack Sherrill
- I never was at a dead-house in my life; I have seen Phillips, but not to speak to him; I do not know Burt by name - I have seen his man near Mr. Rhodes' counting-house many a time; I will not swear I have not seen him a hundred times; I may have said."How are you?" but never talked with him; I never was in Cloth-fair with Reynolds; I came across Smithfield in coming here yesterday and to-day - I was not there three weeks or a month ago; I do not know how long Reynolds has known Burt - I never saw them together in my life; I never was at Camberwell to the best of my knowledge - I never was in Shoreditch church-yard; I do not remember when the dead-house at St. Thomas'-hospital was broken open; I never heard of it - I do not know what you think I am.

ROBERT OYIDEN. I am a special-constable, and live in Gloucester-street, Hoxton. I called Tomkins out of the factory after we had apprehended Chittenden, on the 23rd of December; we went to the Autelope, and I asked if he knew any thing of the robbery - he said he did not; I said, "I don't suspect you, but as foreman, if you know any thing of the robbery, it is your duty to tell us or Mr. Vickers;" he said "God knows, I know nothing of it, and I would give 5l. for the good of the men to knew who did it" - when we came out I said to him, "I suppose you can't tell where to find the notes?" he said, "God knows, I have neither notes nor money, if you were to kick me from here to Hackney-road you would not kick 5s. out of me;" I pointed out his lodgings to Atfield; it is about the centre of Margaret-street, and the name of Evans, carpenter and builder, over the door - it was on the 22nd of December that I was called on by Anderson, and went to the factory; Mr. Vickers gave as a description of Chittenden, and we took him that night on a suspicion of his hand-writing corresponding with that on the envelope in which the cheques were returned - we found him in Bennett's house - Bennett was there- I said to Chittenden, "Will you go with me down to Mr. Vickers, and satisfy him of your innocence, if you can"- I gave him the pen, and he wrote his name; I had seen the writing on the envelop before - he at first hesitated, but he did go and saw Mr. Vickers; I said, "Chittenden, your hand-writing seems to be very much like the writing on the letter, in which the cheques were sent back" - he made no answer, but turned pale; Bennettsaid, "Close, Tom, close," put his hand to his mouth and said, "You know what I mean?" he said, "I should think so;" in taking Chittenden to the watch-house he said, "I am in a b - y pretty mess now, but if I find I am sold, as I think I am, I will sell every b - y one of them."

WILLIAM ATFIELD
. I am a Police-officer. I took Tomkins into custody; I afterwards went to his house in Margaret-street, and found twenty-three sovereigns in a black bag in a blue coat pocket - this is the bag and sovereigns; when I got back to the factory, where Tomkins was in custody of Cope; I asked if he had any thing in his house which did not belong to him - he said No: I asked him what money he had - he said he bad 14l. to pay two years' ground-rent, and that was all; I told him I had found twenty-three sovereigns - he said that was not his, it belonged to his father-in-law; I found them in the back room on the ground floor - I found this bit of paper with some figures on it on the floor.

JOSEPH HUDSON
. I am a labourer, in the employ of the Gas Company; I lodge in the same house with Tomkins, and was at home when the officer searched his house - I know it was his room which was searched; I have seen him wear a blue coat on Sunday.

JAMES BROWN. I am an officer. I took Bennett on the 28th, and he was discharged by the Magistrate - I took him again on the 6th of January; when I was locking him up he said, "If I had known you had been after me again, you should have had some trouble;" this is the paper in which the cheques were sent back.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Then one was discharged? A. Yes; there was no further evidence at the time, but more was received afterwards, and he was committed to Clerkenwell till the indictment was found.

JOHN
GEORGE VICKERS
. I gave this paper to the last witness; it came to me by post - I do not know the writing on the back of it; it contained the cheques which had been stolen - I never saw Tomkins write.

JOHN ANDERSON
. I am an officer, and live in Goldsmith's-row, Hackney-road. I went with Oviden, and took Chittenden - I asked him to write his name on a bit of paper in case it might be wanted; I saw him write it- this is it; I told him to go into the tap-room - I went, and compared his name with the writing on the paper, in which the cheques were sent - I went back to Chittenden and said his writing agreed with that; he seemed to be quite struck, and never said a word - in going to the watch-house he made some observation to Oviden; he seemed to say he had been sold, and if he had known he would have sold the lot - that I understood to be the substance.

RICHARD HANSON
. I am a labourer in the Imperial Gas Company; I know Chittenden, he is a smith - I went into the smith's shop about a fortnight before the robbery; I saw Chittenden there, and asked him to sharpen me some tools, he said, "He could not do it by himself" - he had a key screwed in a vice, and was filing it; I went away, and returned in ten minutes, it was then out of the vice - I saw no more of it; it is not part of his duty to make keys for the factory; I saw the handle of the key, and it appeared to me as if it would fit the outside counting - house door.
Chittenden. This witness knows I had left the place five or six weeks before the robbery. Witness. It was about a fortnight before he was discharged I saw him.

GEORGE EVANS. I am landlord of the Antelope; I remember Tomkins being at my house on the 2d of January, with another manl did not know - they had a quartern of rum, which was entered to Tomkins' account in the book; I was very busy, and did not notice the other.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q.Was it by Tomkins' order you entered it? A. Yes.

Chittenden's Defence. I can prove I was at work on the night of the robbery, and not within three miles of the place; I could have brought four or five witnesses, if I had known that they had been wanted, but I did not expect I should have been on trial at all, as Mr. Bennett discharged us.

WILLIAM BURT
. I am a labouring man. On Friday fortnight I was in Cloth-fair, and met Reynolds against the Hand and Shears; he asked how I got on for work; I said, "I had now and then a day or two's work for Mr. Rhodes" - he said he could tell me of a plan I could get some money by - he said there was a man named Tomkins, foreman of the Gas Company, and I might go and tell him, if he did not give me some money, I would tell his masters that he did the robbery - I said, "I do not know the man, and I will have nothing to do with it" - he said he would go and show him me; he said he had got a good situation, and rather than lose it he would give me some money - he begged I would not mention it.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Did you go to the foreman? A. No; I told this story at different public-houses, and people said if I was any man at all, I should state it - I had seen Reynolds before, but we were not on intimate terms; I have not laboured in Shoreditch church-yard, and I defy any man to face me in that - I cart coals, and do other work - I have worked for Mr. Wise in carting bricks - it is three months since I was in any regular employ; I was then kilnman to Mr. Rhodes - I worked for him two years; I have known Reynolds three months - I have known Sherwin, but never was at Shoreditch church-yard with him - I was never in a prison.

ROBERT OVIDEN
re-examined. I stood over Chittenden while he wrote his name, and gave him the pen; I do, upon my oath, believe the writing on this envelope to be his, the post mark could not be made out - I took it to the Post-office, and they said it was put in at Holborn-bars.
JOHN ANDERSON re-examined. I saw him write his name; I believe he wrote this envelope.
Cross-examined by. MR. HEATON. Q. Do you form that judgement, from seeing him write his name? A. Yes.

JURY to
JOHN GEORGE VICKERS
. Q.Was it usual for you to make up your money on Wednesday night? A. Yes, and to pay it on Thursday; I never saw Reynolds before, and I should think he could not know the money was made up on Wednesday, without some one belonging to the works telling him.
NOT GUILTY .

478.
ELIZABETH SHOULTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March , 1 pillow and case, value 4s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 4s.; 1 pair of blankets, value 8s.; 1 bed cover, value 3s.; 3 flat irons, value 2s.; 1 candlestick, value 2s.; 1 shawl, value 1s., and 1 apron, value 1s. , the goods of
David Ellis
.

ELIZABETH ELLIS
. I am the wife of David Ellis - the prisoner lodged with us in Queen's-court, Holborn
. I missed these things, and have never seen them since; I inquired why her husband did not come; she said he was in the country - in about a fortnight afterwards she left her shop of work, and I heard from another lodger that she had not been in my house for two nights; I went up stairs and looked for the key of her door, but could not find it - I looked through the key-hole, and missed the clothes off the bed; I had the door opened, and there was nothing in the room but an old shift of my daughter's, which she had to mend - I know these articles had been in the room, and the prisoner only, had the key of it.

Prisoner. I went out one morning, and when I returned in the evening I found the door had been broken open; I missed the things - her daughter admitted that she had broken open the door and taken the things.
THOMAS THOMPSON. I had been looking for the prisoner for six months - I found her about the 30th of December; when I asked her about these things; she said they were too far gone.
Prisoner. I said I knew nothing of them - as to the shawl. she gave me that.

ELIZABETH ELLIS
. I did lend it her once - she returned it, and then took it again: three months afterwards I found where she lodged - I took a Police-officer to the place, but she could not be found - she afterwards gave herself up to another officer.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .

479.
ANN READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of January , 1 pair of boots, value 16s. , the goods of
William Huddard Dutton
.

SAMUEL GWYNN. I am a boot-maker, in the service of Mr.
William Huddard
Dutton, in Norton-court
. On the evening of the 6th of January I saw the prisoner lurking about the place; I went out, and asked if she wanted any thing - I looked round the shop, and she dropped the boots at her feet; she had a large cloak on - I had not seen them in her hand; Mr. Groom came by, and we gave charge of her - she said, "I am very sorry for what I have done, and I hope you will look over it."

JOHN GROOM
. I took the prisoner - she begged Mr. Dutton to forgive her, and said it was the first time.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined One Year .

480.
THOMAS MANNING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of January , 1 feather pillow, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Sladden
.

THOMAS SLADDEN
. I am a broker , and live in White's-row, Spitalfields
. On the 8th of January I lost a pillow from my shop - a little boy told me it was gone; I went out in pursuit of the thief, but could not find him - the prisoner was afterwards pointed out, and I took him; I have never seen the pillow since.
Prisoner. There were several persons round the place; I was coming by between five and six o'clock, and he took me. Witness. Yes, there were several boys.
THOMAS SAVAGE. I sell fish. I saw the prisoner take the pillow - he shook it, put it under his arm, and went down Rose-lane; I saw nobody with him - he came up Rose-lane again with some other boys.
THOMAS HART. I received the prisoner at the watch-house - he said he knew nothing of the pillow; I found l on him - he has an industrious poor mother.
NOT GUILTY .

481.
ROBERT BEHARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of January , 1 shovel, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Morris Fenton
.

MORRIS FENTON. I am working at the New College at Somerset-house
. On the 8th of January the prisoner came there and asked for a job - I said we had none; I saw him go away with my shovel under his arm - I did not go after him, as the watchman said if I did I should not get in again till twelve o'clock, and I should lose half a day: I afterwards found him at work with my shovel - this is it; I know it by three notches on the handle, and the iron being turned up.

EDGAR ANDERSON
. I am a Police-officer. The prosecutor told me the prisoner had his shovel, and I took him with it - he said he bought it in the street, and gave 2s. 9d. for it; he then said he gave 3s. for it.
Witnesses for the Defence.

JOHN WATTS
. The prisoner lodged with me. This shovel came into my house bran new six weeks ago.

MOSES WATERS. I cannot swear to this shovel, but six weeks ago last Thursday, I bought one at the corner of Parliament-street, for 2s. 8d. - it had no mark on it; I sold it to the prisoner for the same price - he gave me 3s., and I gave him 3d., which was all I had; I believe this to be it.
JOHN BERRY. The prisoner came to the place for work, and I saw him go out with his hands in his pockets - he had no shovel.
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

482.
JOSEPH HARMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , 3 brass ornaments, value 7l.; 1 watch-case, value 15s.; 10 tea-cups, value 9s.; 11 saucers, value 9s.; 1 basin, value 6d.; 1 milk-jug, value 6d.; 3 salt-cellars, value 2s.; 1 watch-movement and dial, value 18s., and 13 clock bells, value 15s. , the goods of
David Magson
, his master.

DAVID MAGSON
. I am a machinist , and live in Bangor-court, Shoe-lane
- the prisoner was in my employ. On the 8th of December I went out at half-past one o'clock to dinner, leaving him in care of the shop; I returned in about an hour, and he was gone - I missed these articles; he never returned.

WILLIAM HOOKER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 10th - he gave the duplicates up, in my presence, to the prosecutor.

LEONARD CHARLES
MATTHEWS. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Whitecross-street. I have some brass ornaments and watch movements, pawned on the 7th of December, by the witnesses; the officer gave the duplicate up to me - I put it on our file, and have not been able to find it.

MARY CANNON
. I have known the prisoner three years - he gave me these articles, and I pawned them for him with Matthews.

JOHN BENNETT
. I am shopman to Mr. Clark. I have a pair of horses, and some chiming bells, pawned on the 9th of December - the prisoner pawned the horses, and McFarlane the bells.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 41. -
Confined Nine Months .

383.
WILLIAM HASWELL LEACH
was indicted for
a misdemeanor ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

484.
HENRY WILLIAMS
was indicted for
a misdemeanor .

JOHN CROSS
. I keep a butcher's-shop in Leadenhall-market
. On the 6th of December my shop was fastened up safe.

- RAWSON. I am Cross' son-in-law. On the 6th of December, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw two young men trying the shop door; the prisoner was not one of them - one was fitting a key to the door; Ghrimes, the officer, came by, and they ran away; I told him what I had seen, and concealed myself - they came back just after the people were gone to church, about seven o'clock, with the prisoner; they opened the door with a false key - they were all at the door together; the prisoner went in, and shut himself in - the others remained outside; I gave an alarm - the prisoner opened the door, rushed out, and ran about fifty yards; I knocked him down, and stood over him till the officer came.
- GHRIMES. I am an officer. I took the prisoner into custody, and found a jemmy on him, five skeleton-keys, a bit of candle and a gimblet.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going through the market, and saw two men coming from the shop - on the step were these things; I took them up, and went into the house, thinking something was wrong.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Confined Two Years , and
Publicly Whipped .
Before Mr. Recorder.

485.
SAMUEL CLOUGH
was indicted for feloniously
breaking and entering the warehouse of the
United Company of Merchants trading to the East Indies
, on the 29th of November , and stealing therein a quantity of silk and crape shawls, handkerchiefs, scarfs, &c., value 608l. , their property.
MESSRS. BRODRICK and BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM FRENCH
. I am an elder in the East India Company's employ, at their warehouse in Cutler-street, St. Botolph, Aldgate
- the warehouses are divided into compartments, distinguished by letters, and floors by numbers; the prisoner has been eight years in the Company's employ in the tea department, under me; the silk goods are kept in quite another part - on the 28th of November he was employed in the room, No. 53. on the third floor, to mend chests - the room, No. 83, is separated from that by a yard, but connected by a wooden bridge; he had no business whatever in that room: he asked my permission to leave at eleven o'clock that morning for half an hour to breakfast - I gave him leave, and at three, when the men were called over, before leaving work, he was missing.

WILLIAM REA. I am a commodore in the Company's employ. On the 28th of November I had charge of the room No. 83, on the third floor; the prisoner had no business there - I fastened that warehouse up at three o'clock; it was secured by iron doors - it contained chests of tea, piled up for delivery; a person could easily conceal themselves among the chests - on the Monday morning, about nine o'clock, I went to that warehouse, unlocked the door, and found some person had been there, and removed eight chests to make a platform under a loop-hole, which had been fastened up; a person could get on them, and reach the ceiling - there were marks of a crow-bar or instrument having been used to break through the ceiling, but it had not succeeded; there is a window in that room, leading to a staircase - I found the centre iron bar of that window was forced from the frame, and two squares of glass broken, so that they could get on the staircase; and that leads to a trap-door, communicating with a space between the ceiling and roof; there are steps on which a person could get up to the trap-door, and the hinges were forced off it - they could then get on the roof by unbolting another door; I informed French, the elder.

JEREMIAH THOMPSON. I am a commodore in the Company's employ, and had charge of the rooms Nos. 68 and 69, in the Bengal department. On the 26th of November these rooms contained silks of various descriptions, crape, shawls, and very valuable property from China and Madras - I fastened both these rooms at three o'clock in the afternoon with iron doors; I returned on Monday at nine, and on entering No. 68 I found it in the utmost confusion, a number of presses were opened, silk goods taken from them, and scattered about the floor; no force had been used to the door of the room - a quantity of goods were gone from the tables and presses; I discovered two apertures in the ceiling, communicating with the roof - one would admit a man through it from the roof; I went into No. 69, found that in a similar state, and two holes in that ceiling, and a quantity of silk goods taken away; I found a bunch of small keys and a saw on the floor of that room - the boxes, containing the silk, had been opened; I am certain the ceilings of both rooms were entire on the Saturday.

JAMES POPE. I am an elder, in the Company's service. I came to the warehouses, in Cutler-street, a little before nine o'clock: in consequence of an alarm, I went to the roof of the Bengal department, over Nos. 68 and 69, and found two large holes in the roofs of both rooms - a person could get on that roof, through the trap-door of No. 83.

CHARLES BUTLER
. I am one of the Company's labourers. On Monday morning, the 30th of November, a quarter before eight o'clock, I went into the yard, at the back of the warehouse. H. - when I unlocked the door, I heard the back door of the yard slam too; I went into the passage, where a quantity of men's working clothes lay on the floor, as if they had been made a bed of - I went into the back yard, and found a quantity of crape shawls lying outside the door; I saw a rope hanging from the chimney. on the parapet wall - it reached down close to a cistern in the yard; I immediately went up, and locked the door - Bennett was with me; we went into the yard again - Bennett said, "This is a pretty job, whoever hasdone it;" the prisoner then came out of the privy, and said it was of no use, for he had done it - he had neither shirt nor stockings on; the yard is so surrounded by warehouses, nobody could get out of it, unless he went up the the rope again, on the roof; we took him to Mander's station, with the goods in the yard - he had a dry coat on; he asked me to let him have his shirt and stockings, which were up on the landing-place of the first floor, and were wet - I saw a wet coat hanging on the bannisters; his trousers were in the privy, and were wet - he seemed tired- his hands were very much blistered; when we got to the station, he told us there was a quantity of bundles, in a small yard, round in Petticoat-lane (it is Harrow-alley) and that there were goods at the top of the buildings, some in the cistern, and some in the privy - I found goods in all those places; there were ten bundles in Harrow-alley, with long pieces of string tied to them, to let them down - they were goods which had been in the warehouse.

JOSEPH BENNETT
. I am in the Company's employ. Butler called me: I went on the roof, and in different places I found a quantity of loose handkerchiefs, with a rope and crow-bar - the rope came down near the cistern; a man descending by it would come into the cistern - I went into Petticoat-lane, and found goods.

JAMES TONKIN. I am a labourer in the Company's employ; the prisoner was given into my custody - he told me voluntarily that he was at work on Bell's floor, and brought the crow-bar and saw away from there, concealed them in Rae's floor, and after the warehouses were locked up he began to work, got to the roof of the warehouses, and worked himself into the silk-room, made a bed of silk, laid on it till Sunday morning, then began to pack up the goods, and he hoped he had not gone so far as to touch his neck, for if he had he was out of his calculation.

JEREMIAH THOMPSON
. The whole of the goods are worth between 600l. or 700l. without the duty.
Prisoner's Defence. The witness says I said I had not gone far enough to touch my neck, that is false.
JAMES TONKIN. I am certain he used that expression.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Life .
First London Jury. - Before Mr. Recorder.

486.
WILLIAM TURNER
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Robert Armstrong
, on the 3rd of December , and stealing 1 sovereign, and 1 half sovereign , his monies.
The money being the joint property of the prosecutor and another, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

487.
JAMES CLARK
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
MR. ELLIS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE GODFREY. I am the son of the late
George Godfrey
, who has died since this happened: we live in Charterhouse-street, and keep a coal-shed . On the 2nd of January the prisoner came and asked for a peck of coals -I served him; they came to 4 1/2d. - he offered me a crown-piece: I knew it to be bad, and said I had not got change- my father came forward; I said, "This man has tendered me a bad crown-piece" - he shut the door and asked where he got it; he refused to tell, but after some time he said, he took it in change from a woman whom he had slept with the night previous - I said if he wanted the coals to burn he must live in the neighbourhood: he repeatedly refused to say where he lived: and then said he had come from a place close by Edmonton, had just come to town, and had borrowed an apron to fetch the coals, but would not tell where they were to be taken - we sent for Dell, who searched him; I marked the crown, gave it to my father, who marked it, and I saw him give it to the officer; it was not out of my sight.
JOHN DELL. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner, and found two good shillings on him: Godfrey, senior, marked the crown-piece in my presence and gave it to me - I have had it ever since.

ELIZA SAYER
. I am Godfrey's grand-daughter. The prisoner came into the shop on the 1st of January, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, for four bundles of wood and gave me half a crown; I gave him change, and put the half-crown in front of the drawer, which is about three feet long - there were then two sixpence and two shillings in the drawer; there was one half-crown besides, but that was at the further end of the drawer - nobody but me had access to the drawer; my aunt sat by me, and before I shut the drawer, in consequence of what she said, I took the half-crown out and gave it her, immediatley after the prisoner was gone; it was quite at a distance from the other half-crown, and I am sure it was the one he gave me - I made a mark on it with my teeth; it was given to my grandfather, who is dead - I saw him wrap it in paper, and put it into a drawer in the bureau, which is up stairs, the bottom drawer on the right-hand - there was no other money there.

Prisoner. Q.You told the officer I was not the person, and that it was a man of a dark complexion? A. When I first looked at him I thought he was not the person, as he was dressed quite different, and I was not close to him; I thought it was him afterwards - it was five days after when I said he was the person.

ELIZABETH VICKRESS. I am the witness' aunt. I was in the room close to the shop, and saw the prisoner give her the half-crown: she put it in front of the drawer - I was sitting close to the drawer and thought it looked suspicious; she took it out and gave it to me - I know it to be the same as he gave her; it had a black mark on it - I told her to wrap it up and give it to her father when he came in; she put it in front of the drawer, away from the other.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of counterfeit coin; this crown-piece is counterfeit, and made of white metal- no part of it is silver.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it in change of half a sovereign the night previous.
GUILTY of the single uttering only .

Confined 6 Months , and to
find sureties .

488.
JOHN SHERWOOD alias SMITH
, was indicted for
obtaining goods, value 12l. 2s., by false pretences ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

489.
JAMES CANNON
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

490.
JOHN LAPWORTH
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of December , 1 shawl, value 2s., the goods of
Caroline Thornton
; 1 gown, value 1s., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
Charlotte Bates
.
The prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

491.
WILLIAM HARLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 30 yards of flannel, value 1l. , the goods of
John Goodinge
.

ANN GOODINGE. I am the wife of John Goodinge, a linendraper , of Brick-lane, Old-street
. On the 7th of December, I saw the prisoner go out of our shop with this roll of flannel, at a quarter-past six o'clock in the evening; I followed him; he dropped it when he had run about a dozen doors; I had seen his back as he went out of the shop, and as he turned by the shop window I saw his face - I did not see him stopped - a gentleman picked up the flannel and gave it me; he was brought to the shop in two or three minutes by the watchman.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Have you ever seen him before? A. I think I had the night before; I had but a short sight of him, but I followed him for three or four doors - he turned, and I saw his face distinctly by a gas-light.

JOSEPH ALDRIDGE
. I am a watchman; I was going my round at a quarter-past six o'clock, and heard the witness call Stop thief! I turned and heard her call again - in a very short time I saw the prisoner coming across John-street, with something white under his arm; he was the person she appeared to be calling after - he dropped the flannel and ran very fast - I ran across; he ran down Clarendon-street, and I followed him, calling Stop thief! all the way, and a person who keeps a little shop, ran out just in time to stop him - I was very close behind him, and never lost sight of him.

Cross-examined by MR. HEALEY. Q.How far were you from the prosecutor's door, when you first saw the prisoner? A. It might be one hundred yards; he ran in a straight direction to the end of John-street, where he turned - that was two or three hundred yards from where he was stopped; he only turned twice, but I did not lose sight of him -I was a very short distance from him all the way.

WILLIAM CHILD
. I am a green-grocer; I heard a cry of Stop thief! I ran out and stopped the prisoner - I gave him in charge of the watchman; I did not see any thing on his person.
Cross-examined. Q.Was the watchman near him? A. Yes.

WILLIAM VANN
. I am a broker. I was standing at the corner of Brick-lane - I saw the prisoner running with the bundle of flannel; I pursued him till he dropped it - I took it up and gave it to Mr. Goodinge.

Cross-examined. Q.How far from the house did he drop it? A. Perhaps one hundred yards; it was dark, the gas was lighted - that part is very well lighted, it is near the gas-house; I did not see the prisoner stopped; I had not seen him before, but I met him then, and can swear to him.

JOHN BROWN. I am the officer. The prisoner was brought to me with this flannel; I searched, and found on him, this phosphorus-box, and a duplicate of a coat, which he said he had picked up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Mr. Lawrence, in Clarendon-street, to fetch a box for Mr. Henderson, in Howland-street; I had but just got down stairs, when I heard Stop thief! called - I turned in the direction they were running, when I knocked against the man who took me - the watchman came up and said, I had a long coat on, and I was the thief - Mr. Brown would not allow me to send to Clarendon-street.
JOSEPH ALDRIDGE. Clarendon-street was not mentioned then; he asked if he could send to his friend - I did not hear the name of Lawrence.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

492.
THOMAS CRAWFORD
was indicted for
stealing on the 9th of January , 4 lbs. weight of candles, value 2s. 4d. the goods of
Joseph Little
.

JAMES NICHOLS
. I am shopman to Joseph Little, of Norton-falgate
, an oilman . On the 9th of January the prisoner took this paper of candles off the counter in our shop, while I turned round behind the other counter; he dropped them in the shop near the door - he had come in for a halfpenny worth of saitpetre, and I served him - two other boys then came in, and the prisoner stopped while they were served; they then made way to go out, and the prisoner turned and dropped the candles; a watchman came in, and asked it I had lost any thing - I said he had dropped this paper of candles - the prisoner ran across the road and up a court; the watchman pursued and brought him back - he said the boys who came in after him had dropped the candles, but I am certain he dropped them; the other were close to him.

DANIEL HANK
. I am a watchman. On the evening of the 9th of January I had been watching the prisoner and two others for some time - I missed them, and thought they had gone up White Lion-street; I turned, and met my partner - a person touched me on the shoulder and said,"Do you see what is going forward here?" I looked into the prosecutor's shop, and saw the three lads there - the prisoner and another went to the further end of the shop, and then two of them went to the counter - the shopman served them; I saw a brown paper bundle on the counter - the other two lads then went to the door, and the prisoner dropped this bundle from under his coat; I came round, and the other person had let the prisoner slip by him - I told my partner the prisoner had gone across the road; he went and brought him instantly - I had seen him go across the road and run down an alley; I am quite sure he is the person the parcel fell from.

JOHN BURNESS
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner in Mr. Little's shop, but did not see him do any thing - I saw him come out, and run across the road; I kept my eye upon him - he ran up a court, and up two pairs of stairs in a house; I followed, and brought him back - I knew him before.
Prisoner's Defence. I went in to buy something - there were two others in the shop; a boy took the candles, and dropped them by my side.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

493.
SOLOMON COLEMAN
,
RICHARD TOMES
,
THOMAS COOK
,
THOMAS PRICE
, and
JANE TOMES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of January , 10 reams of papers, value 9l. , the goods of
John Key
and
Jonathan Mucklestone Key
.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.
